etymology.description: 很(很) (hěn, "very") and 好(好) (hǎo, "good") combine to form a phrase that means "very good." 很(很) (hěn, "very") is an intensifier used to modify adjectives, while 好(好) (hǎo, "good") describes a positive quality or state.
etymology.interpretation: This combination is frequently used in Mandarin to express a high degree of positivity or approval by intensifying the adjective 好(好) (hǎo, "good").

parts.english: very; quite; much; to a large extent

examples.chinese: 这部电影很好(這部電影很好)。
今天的天气很好(今天的天氣很好)。
他的中文说得很好(他的中文說得很好)，让人印象深刻(讓人印象深刻)。
examples.pinyin: Tā de Zhōngwén shuō de hěn hǎo, ràng rén yìnxiàng shēnkè.
examples.english: His Chinese is very good, leaving a deep impression.
